Imports

coroutines, private/timeoutwatcher

Types

EvDispatcher = ref EvDispatcherObj
Cannot be shared or moved around threads Source   Edit   
OneShotCoroutine = ref object
Coroutine that can only be resumed once inside a dispatcher Source   Edit   
PollFd = distinct int
Reprensents a descriptor registered in the EventDispatcher: file handle, signal, timer, etc. Source   Edit  

Consts

InvalidFd = -1
Source   Edit

proc registerTimer(timeoutMs: int; coros: seq[OneShotCoroutine] = @[];
                   oneshot: bool = true): PollFd {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}
Timer is registered inside the poll, not inside the event loop. Use another function to sleep inside the event loop (more reactive, less overhead for short sleep) Coroutines will only be resumed once, even if timer is not oneshot. You need to associate them to the fd each time for a periodic action Source   Edit   
proc removeFromSelector(oneShotCoro: OneShotCoroutine; byTimer: bool) {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Only consume when not referenced anymore inside dispatcher Source   Edit   
proc resumeImmediatly(coro: Coroutine) {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Will be put at the beggining of the timers queue Can starve the event loop Source   Edit   
proc resumeLater(coro: Coroutine) {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Will be put at the end of the queue Source   Edit   
proc resumeOnTimer(coro: Coroutine; timeoutMs: int) {....raises: [],
    tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}
Equivalent to a sleep directly handled by the dispatcher Source   Edit   
proc resumeOnTimer(oneShotCoro: OneShotCoroutine; timeoutMs: int) {....raises: [],
    tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}
Equivalent to a sleep directly handled by the dispatcher Source   Edit   
proc resumeSoon(coro: Coroutine) {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Will be put at the beggining of the queue Will still be resumed after timers and event loop Source   Edit   
proc runEventLoop(timeoutMs = -1; dispatcher = ActiveDispatcher) {.
    ...raises: [ValueError, CoroutineError], tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}
The same event loop cannot be run twice. The event loop will stop when no coroutine is registered inside it Two kinds of deadlocks can happen when timeoutMs is not set:
  • if at least one coroutine waits for an event that never happens
  • if a coroutine never stops, or recursivly add coroutines
Source   Edit   
proc running(dispatcher = ActiveDispatcher): bool {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}
Source   Edit   
proc runOnce(timeoutMs = -1) {....raises: [CoroutineError], tags: [TimeEffect],
                               forbids: [].}
Run the event loop. The poll phase is done only once For efficiency, timeout is only taken in account for the selector phase. Long calculations can starve the event loop. If that's the case, use resumeLast() regularly. Source   Edit   
proc setCurrentThreadDispatcher(dispatcher: EvDispatcher) {....raises: [],
    tags: [], forbids: [].}
A dispatcher cannot be shared between threads But there could be one different dispatcher by threads Source   Edit   
proc sleepAsync(timeoutMs: int) {....raises: [CoroutineError], tags: [TimeEffect],
                                  forbids: [].}
Source   Edit

    ...raises: [CoroutineError], tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}
Source   Edit

    tags: [], forbids: [].}
See resumeImmediatly Source   Edit   
proc suspendUntilLater(coro: Coroutine = nil) {....raises: [CoroutineError],
    tags: [], forbids: [].}
See resumeLater Source   Edit   
proc suspendUntilRead(fd: PollFd; timeoutMs = -1; consumeEvent = true): bool {.
    ...raises: [CoroutineError], tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}
See also consumeCurrentEvent to avoid a data race if multiple coros are registered for same fd If PollFd is not a file, by definition only the coros in the readList will be resumed It will not try to update the kind of event waited inside the selector. Waiting for unregistered event will deadlock Source   Edit   
proc suspendUntilSoon(coro: Coroutine) {....raises: [CoroutineError], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}
See resumeSoon Source   Edit   
proc suspendUntilTimer(coro: Coroutine; timeoutMs: int) {.
    ...raises: [CoroutineError], tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}
See resumeOnTimer Source   Edit   
proc suspendUntilTimer(timeoutMs: int) {....raises: [CoroutineError],
    tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}
Source   Edit   
proc suspendUntilWrite(fd: PollFd; timeoutMs = -1; consumeEvent = true): bool {.
    ...raises: [CoroutineError], tags: [TimeEffect], forbids: [].}
If PollFd is not a file, by definition only the coros in the readList will be resumed It will not try to update the kind of event waited inside the selector. Waiting for unregistered event will deadlock consumeEvent permits to avoid a data race if multiple coros are registered for same fd Source   Edit   
proc toOneShot(coro: Coroutine): OneShotCoroutine {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}
Source   Edit   
proc unregister(fd: PollFd) {....raises: [ValueError], tags: [], forbids: [].}
It will also consume all coroutines registered inside it Source   Edit   
proc updatePollFd(fd: PollFd; events: set[Event]) {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}
std/selector raise here if fd is not registered Source   Edit   
proc wasWakeUpByTimer(): bool {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}
Only works inside a coroutine resumed by dispatcher Source   Edit  

Templates

template insideNewEventLoop(body: untyped)
Temporarly replace the current event loop. This means, you can't use any AsyncObjects defined before like goStdin, `goStdout. But we can register them in the new dispatcher. And no coroutines defined before will be executed Source   Edit   
template insideNewEventLoop(dispatcher: EvDispatcher; body: untyped)
Temporarly replace the current event loop. This means, you can't use any AsyncObjects defined before like goStdin, `goStdout. But we can register them in the new dispatcher. And no coroutines defined before will be executed Source   Edit   
template withEventLoop(body: untyped)
Ensures all coroutines registered will be executed, contrary to wait Source   Edit
